column1: 2024-10-05T18:29:40Z,newgraph_airvine,newgraph_airvine,newgraph_airvine,Chilako River,Mud rd Bridge upper,,,,,,No,No,10,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,"Recording site here as a place to document site visit to inform Upper Bulkley Streamkeepers. Upper site is rock and peg boarding. Mix with soil placed on top of re-sloped bank. Although high flow events apparently have not happened in the spring since construction. The site seems to be holding up extremely well. Revegetation on the face of the slope is decent with willow growth and Cottonwood fairly significant had an estimated 5% of the cover. There are large amounts of invasive weeds, including Canada, Thistle and common Tansey, however.

Above the cut bank is a mix of agronomic grasses, willow and invasive to the fence line located approximately 8 to 20 m from the top of slope. Seems unlikely that native shrubs planted will eventually dominate cover above the top bank. Planting on the slope would also likely result in better cover in the long term.",,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,AI,,140,,,,,,,,,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_113530.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_113533.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_113536.jpg,Riparian upstream,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_113553.jpg,Riparian downstream,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_113650.jpg,Mid slope upstream,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_113701.jpg,Mid slope downstream ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

2024-10-05T18:39:09Z,newgraph_airvine,newgraph_airvine,newgraph_airvine,Chilako River,Mud rd bridge lower,,,,,,No,No,10,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,"This is a place to record erosion protection site as part of Upper Bulkley Streamkeepers restoration planning. This is the downstream site immediately upstream of the lower mud river Road bridge over the lower Chillo river. This site was completed by MOTI and is primarily riprap only. There is some, very small amount of shrub regrowth within the rock and evidence of some cutting placement in the rock however, cover is very minimal and estimated less than one percent. Above the bank and rock placement appears to be highly compacted with some grass growth and occasional stunted, shrubs, and small conifers",,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,AI,,120,,,,,,,,,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_114410.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_114412.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_114421.jpg,Mid slope upstream ,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_114436.jpg,Mid slope downstream ,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_114451.jpg,Riparian upstream,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_114459.jpg,Riparian downstream,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

2024-10-05T18:50:09Z,newgraph_airvine,newgraph_airvine,newgraph_airvine,Chilako River,Mud River rd left bend middle,,,,,,No,No,10,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,"Site recorded as place to store information regarding thanks stabilization related to Upper Bulkley Streamkeepers. The site is located proximately 200 m upstream of the lower mud river bridge over the Chilako river. Was apparently a collaboration with transportation. There are three distinct sections of the site overall with the current peace documented here being primarily Riprap. Thereâ€™s no peg boarding in this centre section. It is mostly rip off with extensive amounts of willow cuttings placed into the rock during construction as well as large amount of small Woody debris at the bottom of the slope corner. There is essentially no right revegetation beyond the top slope in the section likely because the paved road is immediately adjacent to the other side of the ditch beside the fence line at the top of slope. Extensive colonization in this area with Canada Thistle and agronomic grasses.

On the face of the vegetated riprap slope, there is very good shrub colonization from the cuttings placed within the rock, particularly for the lower half of the slope. For the lower half of the slope is estimated at 35% however Survey was conducted late in the growing season, so likely underestimates the amount of cover at full bloom. As noted the top half of the slope contains very minimal shrub and natural colonization percent cover estimated at 5%",,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,AI,,135,,,,,,,,,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_115809.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_115812.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_115816.jpg,Mid slope upstream,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_115831.jpg,Mid slope downstream ,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_115845.jpg,Riparian upstream ,ignore_mobile/photos/20241005_115853.jpg,Riparian downstream ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">

2024-10-05T19:01:48Z,newgraph_airvine,newgraph_airvine,newgraph_airvine,Chilako River ,Mud River rd left bend Lower,,,,,,No,No,10,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,," Place to keep information regarding erosion protection related to upper Pokley restoration planning.
This is the downstream end of a large amount of work done on the outside left bend of the site located hundred to 400 m downstream of the lower mud river road bridge over the Chilako River

This area was peg, boarded with cottonwood and birch potentially other species of logs at approximately 25 to 40 cm DVH keyed into a slope bank that was subsequently buried with soils that were pulled back in the reshaping process.

Although no large runoff events have occurred since installation of the site appears to be holding up very well. Some recolonization of placed willow cuttings. Percent cover of native is roughly estimated at 4%. At the top of the cut slope. It is difficult to determine if vegetation efforts were conducted as, the area is primarily agronomic, grasses, and herbaceous cover. There is some common however, generally Canada Thistle does not seem to be present. There are occasional willow shrubs regenerating on the top of bank and the recurring available for vegetation is significant and estimated at 30 m at the topupstream side and 50 m at the downstream end.

2024-10-07T20:04:25Z,newgraph_airvine,newgraph_airvine,newgraph_airvine,Kenneth Creek,Culvert downstream armour,,,,,,No,No,10,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,Place to put observations as part of upper Bally recovery planning. This is a highway erosion protection site approximately 50 m downstream of the culvert over Kenneth Creek. Primarily riprap bank protection with two boulder large Woody debris structures placed in stream and very minimal vegetation within the riprap within the bottom 2 m of the slope. Some willow and potentially natural Cottonwood regeneration within the bottom 2 m of the slope. There is no meaningful vegetation to provide inputs cover or future large debris complexity to the stream.          ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,AI,,200,,,,,,,,,,,,ignore_mobile/photos/20241007_130501.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241007_130505.jpg,ignore_mobile/photos/20241007_130517.jpg,Mid slope us,ignore_mobile/photos/20241007_130531.jpg,Mid slope ds,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,"<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC ""-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN"" ""http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/strict.dtd"">
